user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following get_rq_dauth_algo code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 21.17.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of get_rq_dauth_algo.
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3
get_rq_dauth_algo (const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const algo_param)
{
  if (NULL == algo_param->value.str)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5; /* Assume MD5 by default */

  if (algo_param->quoted)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))

      /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

    /* No known algorithm has been detected */
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
  }
  /* The algorithm value is not quoted */
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;

  /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

  /* No known algorithm has been detected */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
If MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ compares algo_param->value.len bytes from the token literal to the buffer (e.g. by calling memcmp(token, algo_param->value.str, algo_param->value.len)) then when algo_param->value.len is greater than the token length (strlen("SHA-512-256") == 11) the call will read past the end of the string literal object, causing an out‑of‑bounds access. For example, if algo_param->value.len == 20 this will attempt to read 20 bytes from the token and thus violate Rule 21.17.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function get_rq_dauth_algo:
#define _MHD_MD5_TOKEN "MD5"
...
#define _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN "SHA-256"
...
#define _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN "SHA-512-256"
...
#define _MHD_SESS_TOKEN "-sess"
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation:
Agent A describes a plausible out‑of‑bounds read, but the report as stated cannot be concluded from the shown code alone. The risk exists only if the helper functions MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ and MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n are implemented such that they blindly compare 'algo_param->value.len' bytes starting from the token literal (e.g. by calling memcmp(token, algo_param->value.str, algo_param->value.len)) without first ensuring the token object is at least that long. In that unsafe implementation scenario, a call with algo_param->value.len > strlen(token) would indeed read past the end of the string literal and violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.

However, the target snippet only shows calls to those helper functions and the token macros; it does not show their implementations. If the helpers compute or limit the comparison length using the token literal length (or otherwise avoid reading beyond the token), there is no violation. Therefore the claim is not proven from the provided code alone. To determine whether Rule 21.17 is actually violated you must inspect the implementations of MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ and MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n and confirm whether they may perform an unbounded memcmp/memcpy/etc. of the runtime length into the (shorter) token literal. If they do, the report is correct; if they perform length checks or use token lengths, the report is incorrect.
